title: Installing DataStax Mission Control on an existing Kubernetes Cluster
description:
In this video, Alexander Dejanovski walks through every detail of installing Mission Control on an existing Kubernetes cluster.

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX
Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastaxdevs?sub_confirmation=1 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastaxdevs

About DataStax Developers:
On the DataStax Developers YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, workshops and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on Apache CassandraÂ©.  Visit https://datastax.com/dev for more free learning resources.

transcript.text: hey folks uh I'm going to show you how to install Mission Control uh with your own kubernetes cluster so for this I'm going to follow uh this uh documentation and we're going to be using GK uh for our kubernetes cluster uh so you should create a standard GK cluster because autopilot does not allow web hooks uh so we rely on web hooks for a few things so that's not going to work for us so you can hit configure and then I'm going to name this cluster demo uh we're going to make it a regional uh cluster so that we can spread our racks uh across zones uh so now let's head to the pool so when you provision uh your instances for Mission Control you have to create two separate node pools so the first one will be named platform uh we're going to use three um well actually one per Zone uh that's going to be enough for us uh so we'll create three nodes uh I'm going to use slight like small instances for the sake of testing but uh in the documentation uh we we have a page around planning your installation and uh what type of uh instances you should be using uh depending on the type of not pool uh so here just for the sake of testing uh we'll use E2 medium and we're going to indicate a label for this note pool so that we can then schedule uh our pods accordingly so I'll add the platform roll label here and I'm going to move on and create a second poll which will name database uh that's going to host our DSU or Cassandra so uh yeah let's choose uh three per zone so that's going to be good and then we're going to use slightly beefier instances so I'm going to go to indicate which role this one has uh through the r label and the value will be database okay so we're good to go uh this is going to take a few minutes and then we'll head back and install mission gigs for the compactor uh 50 gigs for the sore Gateway and at least 100 gigs for the ingestor otherwise they may run out of this space fairly quickly and uh since they are deployed as stateful sets uh you cannot easily change the volume size uh afterwards uh so let's apply these so 10 gigs and I think it was 50 gigs for the store Gateway okay then logs you can tune the topology uh of Loki as well
